awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  EAGER--Evaluating Fluid Inclusion Geochemistry of U-Th Dated Speleothems as a Tool for Resolving Paleoclimate Controversies in the American Southwest
awd_abstract_narration:
Global hydrologic reorganization throughout the Northern Hemisphere occurred synchronously with repeated large, sub-millennial-scale climate changes in the northern North Atlantic region during the last deglaciation. However, how this reorganization affected the continental hydroclimate in the drought-prone American Southwest remains poorly resolved. Continental-based paleoclimate reconstructions for this region are contradictory in large part due to two sources of discrepancy: (1) uncertainty in age constraints, and (2) fundamental ambiguity in speleothem-based proxy records.

This project-- a collaborative effort between scientists from the University of California at Davis and Harvard University-- seeks to resolve the apparent contradictions in the inferred glacial-interglacial climate reconstructions for the American Southwest using cave deposits from the Sierra Nevada in California. The researchers will employ novel techniques to generate both a robust chronologic framework (using U-Th dating via laser ablation MC-ICPMS) and a record of precipitation (using temperature-dependent noble gas concentrations in fluid inclusions as a temperature proxy independent of other climate processes and stable isotopic composition of inclusion fluids as a more direct proxy of precipitation composition and source region) over the past ~20,000 years at the study site. Successful proof-of-concept of these innovative approaches would open the door for applications to a wide variety of questions in paleoclimate.

The outcomes of this work should lead to better understanding of how climate change impacts the hydroclimate of the American Southwest, an area that is vulnerable to water resource limitation. Additional broader impacts include development of a new facility for routine high-precision U-series dating (of which there are only a handful in the US), development of the noble gas proxy in carbonates, and training of graduate students at two institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied two stalagmites obtained from caves in the western foothills of the Sierra Nevada, CA which we previously documented capture the paleoclimate of the last deglaciation (past 20,000 years). The project had two primary societally relevant goals:

1) To improve the chronology of speleothem paleoclimate proxy records developed at UC Davis by developing our ability to produce high-precision U-series dates on carbonates in-house.

2) A Proof-of-concept study of the potential of using temperature-dependent noble gas concentrations in fluid inclusions within the stalagmites as an independent proxy of temperature. We further were testing the feasibility of analyzing stable isotopic compositions of inclusion fluids as a more direct proxy of precipitation composition and source region.

Both research goals are intrinsically linked by our longer-term objective to test the hypothesis that past mean warmings in the Northern Hemisphere were associated with reduced precipitation and a possible shift in moisture source in California.

During this project we carried out several laboratory studies and experiments in order to address our scientific objectives. These activities included (1) drilling two additional cores through a large stalagmite from Moaning Cave, CA which extends our record through the last glacial-interglacial cycle of the past 120,000 years; (2) carrying out X-ray CT imaging and neutron tomography of the two stalagmites in order to better evaluate the distribution of fluid-, air- and fluid-, and solely air-filled inclusions within the growth bands of the speleothems; (3) analysis by laser ablation multicollector and progressive step-crushing using a vacuum piston crusher coupled to a noble gas mass spectrometer of the noble gas concentrations and stable (O and H) compositions if the fluid inclusion waters of the stalagmites; and (4) conducting a series of strategically designed laboratory experiments and tests in order to improve the accuracy and precision of U-Th dating of carbonates at UCD.

Our primary results and outcomes include the following. Integrating the results of imaging by X-ray CT and neutron tomography permitted us to develop high-resolution 3-D maps of air- or air- and fluid-filled vs. fully fluid-filled inclusions of inclusions, including finding multiple many mm-wide fluid-filled inclusions. This coupled approach has not been previously applied to stalagmites to our knowledge and served to focus our sampling via laser ablation and extraction by crushing for the geochemical analyses. The include multiple image slices through each speleothem showing textures, inclusion/vug distributions, 3-D printed to-scale models of each stalagmite, and a movie of the integrated X-ray CT and neutron tomography imaging. The movie and 3-D prints will be part of a display being developed for the visitor center at Moaning Cave.

The Sierra Nevada stalagmites yielded generally high water contents documenting their potential for noble gas thermometry. Notably, large differences in the water content of samples correlate with major changes in growth rate estimated from the U-Th ages as well as with shifts in geocheimcal compositions. This suggests that the differences in water content within the stalagmite samples may be linked to the water supply of the speleothem this hypothesis needs to be further tested. Noble gas temperatures and measured dH and d18O values of the fluid inclusion waters in the stalagmites indicate the potential for successfully using these methods of analysis for the fluid inclusions in the Sierra Nevada stalagmites. Lastly, the laboratory experiments and tests we designed to improve the accuracy and precision of U-Th dating of carbonates at UCD successfully led to increased accuracy and precision of U-Th carbonate ages comparable to age data for the same speleothem produced in other laboratories (Berkeley Geochronology Center and Massachusetts Institute of Technology). Based on the inter-laboratory comparisons we made, we are confident that we are producing accurate age data for carbonates with ages varying from 200 years to secular equilibrium of millions of years.

The results have been disseminated a mutiple national and international professional meetings and through publication of several manuscripts. This NSF funding permitted the training of one female post-doctoral scholar, one graduate students and two undergraduate students including a 'first generation to college' student and a Mexican-American.
